data.text: @celinegounder AMA still believes in masks. And I think test to treat is a great idea.
@celinegounder gee I know a hospital pharmacist whose primary job is to review patient charts to make sure docs did not screw up w drug interactions.

@celinegounder NOT necessarily, if you get your medications from more than one pharmacy as I do. My maintenance medications come from a mail-order pharmacy (Caremark), but I would be getting a 5-day course of Paxlovid from Walgreens. So any interactions might be missed.

@celinegounder ...saying, "You couldn't be allergic to Sulfa.  No one's allergic to Sulfa anymore."  And that was how I learned how much Benadryl my body could tolerate.

My regular doctor let me sit in his office and put the call on speaker phone when he reamed that doc out.

@celinegounder ..."Oh my system flagged that, but it hardly ever happens so just go ahead and take it."

I then told them the story about how I found out I had a Sulfa allergy - it started small, I called it in to a cross-coverage doc, and he pooh-poohed me...

@celinegounder A physician once gave me a new prescription, and when I got to the pharmacy, the pharmacist said, "this doesn't work with your Sulfa allergy."

I reached out to my doctor and let them know, to which they replied...

@celinegounder AMA is political and known for blocking alternate medicine use in the US. Countries like Finland, Germany use a lot of homeopathy and in my last visit I noticed there is a flow of Ayurvedic medicine too. AMA will not allow simply because there is fortune to be made .

3/ 25% of Americans don't have a primary care provider & will have difficulty accessing testing and treatment for COVID through a doctor's office.
https://t.co/HyL2vdp7Qv

If only doctors can prescribe Paxlovid, it will result in health inequities.
@celinegounder And trying to reach the physicians to get a simple question answered is not for the faint hearted. That’s more like a mini colonoscopy!
@celinegounder I’d argue this doesn’t benefit physicians at all. Scope of practice excuses applied here & not where it really matters. Pretty sure pharmacists know about drug interactions, y’all…
